tn.text: The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "On the day the Israelites defeated the army of King Jabin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Translate this name as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:04|4:4]].
Translate these names as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:06|4:6]].

tn.ref: when the people gladly volunteer for war
tn.text: "when the men agree to fight in battle"
Deborah and Barak's song continues using poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]])

tn.ref: Listen, you kings! Pay attention, you leaders
tn.text: Deborah and Barak speak to the kings and leaders as if they were there listening to the song. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
This refers to kings and leaders in general, not to specific kings or leaders.

tn.ref: when you went out from Seir, when you marched from Edom
tn.text: This refers to the time when the Israelites left Edom to start conquering the people in Canaan. Yahweh empowering his people to defeat the people of Canaan is spoken of as if he were a warrior leading the Israelite army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Seir is a mountain on the border of the land of Israel and Edom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: the earth shook, and the skies also trembled; also the clouds poured down water
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) this is poetic language that emphasizes Yahweh's power by describing it as causing earthquakes and storms or 2) the people of Canaan being terrified as the Israelites were about to attack them is spoken of as if the earth and sky were shaking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Deborah and Barak's song continues using poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]])

This probably refers to earthquakes and gives the impression that the mountains quaked because they were very afraid of Yahweh. AT: "The mountains trembled in fear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "face" refers Yahweh's presence. AT: "in the presence of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
When Moses and Israel were at Mount Sinai, it quaked. AT: "long ago, even Mount Sinai quaked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "days" represents a longer period of time. AT: "During the lifetime of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

These are the names of people. See how you translated Shamgar and Anath in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:03:31|3:31]] and Jael in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:17|4:18]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Shamgar's father is mentioned to help identify Shamgar and when he lived. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

This can be stated in active form and you can make explicit why the roads were abandoned AT: "people stopped using the main roads; because they were afraid of Israel's enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to smaller roads that fewer people traveled on.

tn.ref: a mother took command in Israel
tn.text: This speaks of Deborah's leadership as if she were the mother of the Israelites. AT: "I took care of the Israelites like a mother takes care of her children" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "the people of Israel worshiped new gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: there was fighting at the city gates
tn.text: Here "gates" represents the entire city. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "enemies attacked the people within the Israelite cities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: there were no shields or spears seen among forty thousand in Israel
tn.text: This statement is probably an exaggeration about how few weapons the Israelites had. AT: "few weapons for battle remained in Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"40,000 in Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: My heart goes out to the commanders of Israel
tn.text: The word "heart" represents a person's emotions. The phrase "My heart goes out to" is a way of saying that Deborah feels gratitude or appreciation. AT: "I appreciate the commanders of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: you who ride on white donkeys ... you who walk along the road
tn.text: This contrast probably refers to rich people and poor people. AT: "you rich people who ride on white donkeys ... you poor people who walk along the road" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
These rugs were probably used as saddles on the donkey's back to make the rider more comfortable.
The song of Deborah and Barak continues.
Here "voices" represents the people singing. AT: "Listen to those" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: went down to the city gates
tn.text: Here "gates" represents the whole city. AT: "returned to their cities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Deborah and Barak's song continues using poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]])
Possible speakers are 1) the people of Israel or 2) Deborah who is speaking to herself or 3) the poet who wrote the song.
Translate this name as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:04|4:4]].
Translate these names as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:06|4:6]].
The word "me" refers to Deborah.

tn.ref: from Ephraim, whose root is in Amalek
tn.text: The people of Ephraim living in the land where the descendants of Amalek originally lived is spoken of as if the people of Ephraim were planted and their roots grew into the land. AT: "from Ephraim, that land where the descendants of Amalek once lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "you" refers to the people of Ephraim. It can be stated in third person. AT: "followed them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This is the place where the descendants of Machir live. Machir was the son of Manasseh and the grandson of Joseph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: from Zebulun those who carry an officer's staff
tn.text: Military leaders are described by the staff, a symbol of their authority. AT: "military leaders from Zebulun" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: My princes in Issachar were with Deborah
tn.text: Here "My" refers to Deborah. This whole statement can be translated in first person. AT: "My princes in Issachar were with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Translate this name as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:04|4:4]].
Here "Issachar" refers to the tribe of Issachar. AT: "the tribe of Issachar was with Barak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Translate this name as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:06|4:6]].

tn.ref: rushing after him into the valley under his command
tn.text: "obeying his command and rushing after him into the valley"
"following after" or "hurrying after"

tn.ref: there were great searchings of heart
tn.text: Here "heart" represents thoughts. The people discussing with each other but being unable to decide what they should do is spoken of as if they were searching their heart. AT: "there was a lot of discussing about what they should do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Why did you sit between the fireplaces, listening to the shepherds playing their pipes for their flocks?
tn.text: This question is asked to criticize the people of Reuben because they did not decide to come fight in the battle. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should have helped us fight, instead of staying at home and listening to the shepherds playing their pipes for their flocks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Some versions of the Bible have the translation "the sheepfolds" or "the sheep pens."

tn.ref: there were great searchings of heart
tn.text: Here "heart" represents thoughts. The people discussing with each other but being unable to decide what they should do is spoken of as if they were searching their heart. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:05:15|5:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "Gilead" represents the men from Gilead who should have gone to fight in battle. AT: "The men of Gilead stayed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the other side of the Jordan
tn.text: This refers to the east side of the Jordan. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: and Dan, why did he wander about on ships?
tn.text: This question is asked to express anger because the people of the tribe of Dan would not fight for Israel. AT: "and the men of Dan should not have remained on their ships" or "and the people of the tribe of Dan did not help us in the battle. Instead they were wandering around on the sea in ships." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "Dan" represents the men from Dan who should have gone to fight in battle. AT: "the men of Dan, why did they" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The tribe of Dan was located near the Mediterranean sea. They sailed on the sea to make money through trade and fishing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Asher remained on the coast and lived close to his harbors
tn.text: The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "The people of the tribe of Asher also failed to help us, they just remained on the coast near their harbors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "Asher" represents the men who should have gone to fight in battle. AT: "The men of Asher remained" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
places at the seacoast with deeper water where ships were kept
You can make clear the understood information. AT: "Naphtali was a tribe who would also risk their lives to the point of death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: The kings came, they fought ... the kings of Canaan fought
tn.text: The king of a people group is used to refer to the army he commands. AT: "The kings and their armies came and fought ... the kings of Canaan and their armies fought" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The word "us" is understood. AT: "they fought us ... fought us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Translate the names of these places as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:01:27|1:27]].
Here "silver" represents any treasure in general. AT: "no silver or other treasures as plunder" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
things taken by force, usually in battle or by thieves

tn.ref: From heaven the stars fought, from their paths across the heavens they fought against Sisera
tn.text: Yahweh helping the Israelite to defeat Sisera and his army is spoken of as if the stars themselves fought against Sisera and his army. This may refer to Yahweh using natural elements, specifically rain storms, to defeat Sisera. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Here "Sisera" represents his whole army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Translate this name as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:01|4:2]].

tn.ref: The Kishon River swept them away
tn.text: Because of the heavy rain the river flooded quickly causing the chariots to be stuck in the mud and drowning many soldiers. AT: "The Kishon River flooded and swept away Sisera's soldiers"   (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Translate this the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:06|4:6]].

tn.ref: March on my soul, be strong
tn.text: Here "soul" refers to the whole person. The word "my" refers to Deborah. AT: "I tell myself to march on and to be strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Then the sound of horses' hooves—galloping, the galloping of his mighty ones
tn.text: This describes the sound of many horses running away from the battle. AT: "Then I heard the sound of horses running away. Sisera's mighty horses were running away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
to run quickly
Here "Meroz" represents the people who lived there. AT: "Curse the people of Meroz" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
the people who live in a place
Translate this name as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:17|4:18]].
Translate this name as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:11|4:11]].
Translate the name of this people group as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:01:16|1:16]].
Here "butter" refers to curdled milk. This was the best milk and a favorite drink among Jael's people. AT: "brought him yogurt" or "brought him curds"
This phrase means the dish was of the best quality because princes were given the best things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: She put her hand to the tent peg
tn.text: "Jael grabbed the tent peg with her left hand"
This is a pointed piece of wood or metal, like a large nail, that is hammered into the ground to hold down a corner of a tent. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:21|4:21]].

tn.ref: and her right hand to the workman's hammer
tn.text: This can be stated as a complete sentence. AT: "and she grabbed a hammer with her right hand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This is a heavy tool made of wood used to hit a tent peg into the ground. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:21|4:21]].
Translate this name the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:04:01|4:2]].
without strength or movement
This can be stated in active form. AT: "she killed him" or "he died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a frame in the window made of crossed wood.

tn.ref: Why has it taken his chariot so long to come? Why have the hoofbeats of the horses that pull his chariots been delayed?
tn.text: Both of these questions mean the same thing. These two statements can be combined. AT: "Why is it taking Sisera so long to arrive home" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: taken his chariot ... Why have the hoofbeats of the horses that pull his chariots
tn.text: Both of these represent Sisera. AT: "taken Sisera ... Why has he" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
A "princess" is the daughter of a king, but a "princess" can also mean female advisers to the king's family. AT: "wisest ladies"

tn.ref: she gave herself the same answer
tn.text: "she said to herself the same thing"

tn.ref: Have they not found and divided up the plunder?
tn.text: The women use a question to emphasize that they believe this is what certainly happened.  AT: "They must have so much plunder that it is taking a long time to divide it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: —A womb, two wombs for every man ... of those who plunder?
tn.text: The women use a question to emphasize that they believe this is what certainly happened. AT: "There must be a womb, two wombs for every man ... of those who plunder." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: A womb, two wombs for every man
tn.text: Here "womb" represents a woman. Sisera's mother believes Sisera's men have captured many women. AT: "Each soldier will receive a woman or two"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"colored cloth" or "colored clothes"
"nicely stitched"

tn.ref: for the necks of those who plunder
tn.text: Here "necks" represents Sisera's soldiers. AT: "for the soldiers who plunder to wear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"let those who love Yahweh"

tn.ref: like the sun when it rises in its might
tn.text: The people of Israel wish to be like the sun that rises because no nation's army is powerful enough to stop the sunrise. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Here "the land" represents the people of Israel. AT: "and the people of Israel lived peacefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"for 40 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
